[[File:Helles im Glas-Helles (pale beer).jpg|thumb|right|A glass of ''Helles'']] '''Helles''' or '''Hell''' is a traditional German [[pale lager]] beer, produced chiefly in Southern Germany, particularly [[Munich]]. The German word ''hell'' can be translated as "bright", "light", or "pale".
==Flavor profile== Helles-style beers typically are full-bodied, mildly sweet, and light-colored, with low bitterness. The beer is clear due to filtration prior to bottling,<ref name=legalimage>{{cite web |url=http://www.legalimage.de/bierkunde-bier-gerstensaft-reinheitsgebot.html |title=Kleine feine Bierkunde |last1=Jositz |first1=Sigrid |date=n.d. |website=legalimage.de |access-date=2015-10-22}}</ref> although some restaurants and breweries do offer an unfiltered version.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Helles & Dunkles: Die besten Berliner Bier-Brauereien, Brauhäuser & Biergärten |url=http://www.morgenpost.de/berlin-aktuell/article108440009/Die-besten-Berliner-Bier-Brauereien-Brauhaeuser-Biergaerten.html |newspaper=[[Berliner Morgenpost]] |date=2012-08-01 |access-date=2015-10-22 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.schanzenbraeu.de/biere.html Schanzenbräu Hell]</ref> Munich-style Helles is a yellow beer brewed with [[lager|bottom-fermenting]] yeast, bitter hops such as [[Hallertau hops]], and a specific gravity between 1.044 and 1.053 (11 to 13 [[plato scale|degrees plato]], and between 4.5 and 6% [[alcohol by volume]]. Helles has a less-pronounced hop flavor than pilsner beers.<ref name=legalimage />
==History== Until the 1960s, Helles were universally available in German-speaking regions. In many regions, Helles was slowly replaced by [[Pilsner]]-style beers,<ref name=derberater>{{cite web |url=http://www.derberater.de/genuss-lebensart/trinken/bier/pils-oder-helles-wo-liegt-der-unterschied.htm |title=Pils oder Helles: Wo liegt der Unterschied? |last=Geyer |first=Tim |date=n.d. |website=derberater.de |access-date=2015-10-22 |quote=}}</ref> which was also driven by changing consumer preferences from draft beer to bottled beer. In regions outside of Southern Germany, Helles is regaining popularity, particularly [[Berlin]], where the beer's traditional image has become trendy.<ref name=tagesspiegel>{{cite web |url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/wirtschaft/augustiner-in-berlin-ein-helles-bitte/1864594.html |title=Augustiner in Berlin: Ein Helles, bitte |last1=Baumstieger |first1=Moritz |date=2010-06-20 |website=tagesspiegel.de |publisher=[[Der Tagesspiegel]] |access-date=2015-10-22 |quote=}}</ref>
==Distribution== Helles enjoys great popularity in the [[Southern Germany|Southern German]] regions of [[Bavaria]], [[Franconia]], and [[Baden-Württemberg]]. It can be referred to as "Helles", "Spezial", "Landbier", "Munich Lager", or "Export". No clear distinction is drawn between Lager and Export, although Export typically is closer in style to [[Dortmunder Export]], which has a slightly higher [[ABV]] of 5.5% for extended shelf life.<ref name=legalimage />
